verses.text: Out of the depths I cry to you, O LORD;
O Lord, hear my voice. Let your ears be attentive to my cry for mercy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 130 The psalm is a complaint of a special kind, since the author does not ask for the destruction of the enemy, but meekly turns to God for forgiveness of his own sins.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130:1
rsbNotes.text: 130:1 Out of the depths. The allusion is to the deep waters of sorrow that overwhelm the psalmist (18:14 and notes).

verses.text: If you, O LORD, kept a record of sins, O Lord, who could stand?

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130:3
rsbNotes.text: 130:3 who could stand. The psalmist is well aware that there is no one without sin (Ps. 53:1–3; Rom. 3:9–20).

verses.text: But with you there is forgiveness; therefore you are feared.
I wait for the LORD, my soul waits, and in his word I put my hope.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130:4
rsbNotes.text: 130:4 there is forgiveness. See 103:3; Ex. 34:7; Luke 7:49; Eph. 2:4, 5. The perception of God’s mercy helps the heart to rightly cultivate the fear of the Lord.

verses.text: My soul waits for the Lord more than watchmen wait for the morning, more than watchmen wait for the morning.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130:6
rsbNotes.text: 130:6 watchmen for the morning. The phrase expresses not only the intense yearning of the poet, but also the certainty of his hope.

verses.text: O Israel, put your hope in the LORD, for with the LORD is unfailing love and with him is full redemption.
He himself will redeem Israel from all their sins.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 130:7
rsbNotes.text: 130:7 O Israel. The writer now calls upon the whole nation to share his penitence and hope.
